description: From Middle English myschevous, mischevous, from Anglo-Norman meschevous, from Old French meschever, from mes- (“mis-”) + chever (“come to an end”) (from chef (“head”)). Synchronically analyzable as mischief +‎ -ous.

adjectives.description: mischievous (comparative more mischievous, superlative most mischievous)

examples: Matthew had a twin brother called Edward, who was always mischievous and badly behaved.
